basics.name: Yohana Kefella
basics.label: Bioinformatics Analyst
basics.summary:
Hi! I'm a Bioinformatics Analyst at Boston University Chobanian & Avedisian School of Medicine. I support research on molecular alterations underlying bronchial premalignant lesions, precursors to lung squamous cell carcinoma. My responsibilities include:

- Maintaining and enhancing RNA-seq pipelines (WDL/Terra) for NIH Human Tumor Atlas data
- Performing preprocessing, quality control, and metadata curation for multi-omic datasets
- Managing and uploading data for the Lung Pre-Cancer Atlas Data Portal to meet data-sharing requirements
- Conducting bulk and single-cell RNA-seq analyses for lung precancer and chemoprevention studies
- Collaborating with trainees and faculty to analyze multi-omic data
- Contributing figures, methods, and text for manuscripts and grant proposals

courses: Computational Methods â€“ 1 and 2, Bioinformatics Programming, Machine Learning, Data Analytics

work.summary: Boston University Chobanian & Avedisian School of Medicine, Boston MA
highlights: Maintain, update, and enhance a RNA-Seq pipeline (written in WDL) developed to process NIH Human Tumor Atlas Network Data using the Terra cloud platform
Possess extensive experience in designing, developing, and optimizing workfolw descriptive language (WDL)  for high-throughput analysis workflows
Conduct multi-omic data preprocessing, quality control, and metadata curation
Support data management and data upload for the Lung Pre-Cancer Atlas Data Portal to comply with data sharing mandates
Perform data analyses on bulk and single-cell RNA-seq data to scientifically advance Lung Pre-Cancer Atlas and lung chemoprevention projects
Collaborate with PhD trainees, post-doctoral fellows, and faculty to process and analyze multi-omic data
Contribute methods, results, figures, and text to scientific manuscripts, white papers, and grant applications

work.company: Systems Biology Group, Merck Co & Inc., Exploratory Science Center
highlights: Implemented supervised machine learning pipelines for omics data
Utilized Snakemake and Nexflow to establish reproducible ML pipelines
Utilized predictive modeling for mechanistic hypothesis generation and biomarker discovery in the microbiome field
Presented results at collaborative meetings with internal research groups
Engaged with scientists to understand their data analysis challenges and develop ideas on how to manage their workflow
Worked on implementing a Mass Spectrometry Data Analysis Pipeline
Created interactive Rshiny applications to automate generation of SLD template, sample ID, load and retrieve Mass Spectrometry data from SQL database

Project experience.position: Impact of oral supplementation of sulforaphane for 12 months on lung cancer-related gene expression in former smokers at high risk for lung cancer: Results from a randomized placebo-controlled phase II clinical trial
highlights: The overall goal was to examine whether oral intake of sulforaphane for 12 months impacts the gene expression of previously identified lung cancer- and premalignant lesion-related gene signatures in bronchial and nasal brushing samples
Pre-processed and conducted quality control on bulk RNA-seq data from bronchial and nasal brushings using an RNA-seq cloud-based pipeline

Curated previously published NRF2, smoking, and lung cancer-associated gene signatures and identified signatures perturbed by sulforaphane treatment.  Identified similarities and differences between the nasal and bronchial brush gene signature scores associated with treatment using linear mixed effect models. Sulforaphane treatment over 12 months impacted lung cancer-associated expression in nasal but not in bronchial tissue from former smokers

Identified genes up- and down-regulated with treatment that were similar and different between nasal and bronchial brushes using linear mixed effect models.  The biology and cell type specificity of these genes was examined to identify potential sulforaphane effects on the epithelium

Project experience.position: Single-cell landscape of lung squamous cell premalignancy in the NTCU induced mice model
highlights: The overall goal is to understand the molecular and cellular alterations via scRNA-seq associated with lung squamous premalignant lesion development and progression in the N-nitroso-tris-chloroethylurea (NTCU) mouse model.   Sensitive (A/j) and resistant (C57BL/6J) strains of mice to NTCU were utilized to allow for characterization of alterations associated with repair versus lesion progression

Pre-processed and conducted quality control on the scRNA-seq data, performed clustering using different subsets of cell and different clustering methods, performed differential compositional analysis to identify cell states changes associated with strain, age, and lesion severity, identified copy number alterations in epithelial cells, and phenotyped cell clusters based on other mouse and human lung scRNA-seq datasets

Results suggest the expansion of a Keratin 5+ basal population in carcinogen-treated A/J mice with severe lesions that harbors copy number and gene expression alterations that may promote tumorigenesis. A subset of these alterations are shared with human lung squamous cell carcinoma, supporting the utility of the NTCU mouse model as a preclinical tool for understanding the mechanism that drive LUSC tumorigenesis

manuscripts.position: Epithelial miR-149-5p up-regulation is associated with immune evasion in progressive bronchial premalignant lesions
Placental transcriptome analysis in opioid-exposed versus non-opioid exposed pregnancies
Attention-based deep learning for analysis of pathology images and gene expression data in lung squamous premalignant lesions
